Scheme 1 Retention of stereoconfiguration or epimerization of cis-1,2-DMCH upon hydroxylation. The epimerization route commonly suggests the participation of long-lived alkyl radicals. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Two general pathways of interaction of m-CPBA with a metal (Mn): (a) heterolytic or (b) homolytic splitting of the OO bond of m-CPBA. Scheme 2 Scheme 3 Oxidation of R-(–)-menthyl acetate with m-CPBA, catalysed by cobalt or iron phthalocyanine in the presence of nitric acid promoter. Data are shown for 90 min reaction time. Scheme 3 Scheme 4 Incorporations of 18O into the tertiary trans-alcohols, products of oxidation of trans-decaline with m-CPBA in the presence of nitric acid promoter and H2 18O, catalysed by phthalocyanine complexes of Co, Fe and Ni. Data are shown for 90 min reaction time. General conditions are as those for Entry 30, Table 4. Scheme 4 Fig. 1 The activities of the catalysts in the oxidation of cis-1,2-DMCH with m-CPBA (Table 1). Yields (sums of 3° and 2° products) are based on m-CPBA. The cis/trans ratio is the number of moles of tertiary cis-alcohol per mol of trans-alcohol. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Accumulations of tertiary trans- and cis-alcohols in the course of cis-1,2-DMCH oxidation with m-CPBA catalysed by cobalt (top) or iron (bottom) phthalocyanines, in the presence of HNO3 promoter (Entries 5 and 4, Table 1, for 90 min, respectively). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Top: UV/Vis spectrum of an acetonitrile solution of [Co(Pc)] (4 × 10–7 M) (purple line). Grey lines are measured each 2.2 min after addition of HNO3 (5 × 10–3 M). Green line shows the spectrum after 40 min. Bottom: green line shows the same spectrum as above. Grey lines show changes occurring after addition of m-CPBA (2.5 × 10–2 M), reaching the final spectrum (red line), measured after 40 min (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Pronounced retention of stereoconfiguration upon sp3 CH bonds hydroxylation of dimethylcyclohexanes and decahydronaphthalenes with m-CPBA oxidant and a Co-phthalocyanine catalyst Dmytro S. Nesterov ⁎ Oksana V. Nesterova Maximilian N. Kopylovich Armando J.L. Pombeiro Centro de Química Estrutural, Instituto Superior Técnico, Universidade de Lisboa, Av. Rovisco Pais, 1049-001 Lisboa, Portugal Centro de Química Estrutural Instituto Superior Técnico Universidade de Lisboa Av. Rovisco Pais Lisboa 1049-001 Portugal ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A series of phthalocyanine (Pc) complexes of general formula [M(Pc)] (M = Mg, V, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) was tested as catalysts for functionalization of sp3 CH bonds, namely in the mild stereoselective oxidation of cyclic alkanes (isomers of dimethylcyclohexane and decahydronaphthalene) using peroxides as oxidants. A high catalytic activity (yield of products up to 75% based on the oxidant) and outstanding retention of stereoconfiguration of substrates (>95% for isomers of dimethylcyclohexane) was disclosed for the cobalt phthalocyanine catalyst [Co(Pc)] using m-chloroperbenzoic acid (m-CPBA) as oxidant and nitric acid as promoter. The phthalocyanine complexes other than Co are much less active with yields of products <10% and low stereo- and bond selectivities. The main reaction mechanism is proposed not to involve high-valent metal species, as evidenced by 18O-labeling and selectivity studies. The [Co(Pc)]/HNO3/m-CPBA system also catalyses chlorination and bromination of cyclohexane with HCl and N-bromosuccinimide as halogen sources. Keywords Cobalt Phthalocyanine Alkane hydroxylation Alkane halogenation Homogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction Phthalocyanine complexes and their derivatives represent a class of compounds with a wide range of applications, from dyes to electronics and medicine [1–4]. Catalytic properties of phthalocyanines are of special attention, namely due to their recognized high stability and versatility [5]. Thus, the stability of the phthalocyanines makes them useful for those cases where harsh reaction conditions may cause degradation of less stable catalysts, and oxidative functionalization of inert aliphatic CH bonds with strong oxidizing agents is among such processes [6–8]. From another prospective, the abundance of various types of CH bonds raises a question: how the catalytic system discriminates the desired position to be functionalized from others present in the reaction mixture? Such selective CH activation has a great potential for synthetic chemistry and industrial applications, for instance late stage drug functionalization or activation of small molecules [9,10]. Thus, the ideal CH activation catalyst should combine a high activity in oxidation reactions with a high bond and site selectivity; and elaboration of such catalytic systems still remains a challenge. A few classes of metal complexes were developed to overcome the oxidation/selectivity problem, particularly using bio-inspired systems [11,12]. Some natural enzymes are able to cleave CH bonds at ambient conditions utilizing high-valent metal-oxo (HVMO) intermediates [13]. Some artificial complexes of transition metals where coordination environments stabilize such a kind of species can mimic selective biological CH activation pathways (such as the radical rebound mechanism of P450) [14]. The ability of phthalocyanines and porphyrins to stabilize HVMO species is remarkable, and complexes with porphyrin ligands have been extensively investigated as catalysts for CH activation [15]. In contrast to porphyrins, phthalocyanines have not been so much studied in such reactions due to their more complicated synthesis. Phthalocyanines are known to form HVMO species upon reaction with peroxides, e.g., H2O2, tBuOOH and m-chloroperbenzoic acid (m-CPBA) [5,16]. The m-CPBA oxidant [17] stands apart from other peroxides due to the complex reaction mechanism and tendency to oxidize stereoselectively even under metal-free conditions, although with low yields and reaction rates [18]. Thus, we have recently demonstrated a high efficiency of a cobalt and a nickel complex with isoindole ligand in the stereoselective hydroxylation of aliphatic CH bonds with m-CPBA [19]. Considering that those complexes are intermediates in the synthesis of phthalocyanines and related compounds [20–24], it is logical to study the activity of phthalocyanine complexes as well. Hence, herein we report the comparative catalytic activity of a series of known phthalocyanine complexes, [M(Pc)] (M = Mg, V, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn), in the selective oxidation of aliphatic CH bonds employing m-CPBA as a primary choice oxidant. In order to better understand the difference between mechanisms of action of various phthalocyanine complexes, we performed a comparative investigation using 18O-labeling and selectivity studies. 2 Experimental The chemicals and the phthalocyanine complexes (Sigma-Aldrich, Acros and Alfa Aesar) were used as received. All experiments were carried out in air. UV /vis spectra were recorded using Perkin-Elmer Lambda 35 spectrometer in a 200 − 800 nm spectral range. 2.1 Catalytic oxidation of alkanes The reactions were typically carried out in air in thermostated cylindrical vials with vigorous stirring. Phthalocyanine and its complexes were used in a form of freshly prepared stock solutions in acetonitrile (ca. 5 mg in 50 mL). Due to limited solubility of phthalocyanines in acetonitrile [25], the stock solutions were ultrasonicated during a few minutes and then an aliquot of the fine suspension was quickly taken to the reaction vial. Then 1–3 mL CH3CN, 0.5 mL of CH3NO2 stock solution (internal standard; 1 mL of CH3NO2 mixed with 9 mL of CH3CN), 45 μL of promoting agent (HNO3 was used in the form of a stock solution in acetonitrile) and 70 μL of cis-1,2-dimethylcyclohexane were added (for other substrates the volumes were calculated to reach the final concentration of 0.1 M). Solid m-chloroperbenzoic acid (m-CPBA) oxidant was dissolved in acetonitrile (typically 30 mg in 1 mL of CH3CN) and the solution was added dropwise within 10 s to a warm (50 °C) solution of other components under vigorous stirring. The other peroxides were used in the same manner. (CAUTION. The combination of peroxides with organic compounds at elevated temperatures may be explosive!). The total volume of the reaction solution was 5 mL. The additives, where used, were added into the vial prior to the addition of the oxidant. For the chromatographic analysis, the samples were quenched at room temperature with excess of solid PPh3 [26] and analysed by GC and GC–MS techniques. Retention of stereoconfiguration (RC) index was calculated as follows: │RC│ = (cis – trans) / (cis + trans) × 100, where cis and trans are concentrations of the respective tertiary alcohols. The commercial substrate, cis-1,2-dimethylcyclohexane, contained 0.86% of trans-isomer which was taken into account for RC index estimation. 2.2 Gas chromatography A Perkin-Elmer Clarus 600 gas chromatograph equipped with two capillary columns, one having an EI-MS (electron impact) detector and the other one with a FID detector, was used for analyses of the reaction mixtures. The GC sequences were selected depending on the columns type. For the non-polar columns (SGE BPX5; 30 m × 0.22 mm × 25 μm): 50 °C (3 min), 50–120 °C (8 degrees per minute), 120–300 °C (35 degrees per minute), 300 °C (3.11 min), 20 min total run time; 200 °C injector temperature. For analysis of oxidation products of highly-boiling compounds, such as adamantane, different conditioning was employed: 50 °C (3 min), 50–150 °C (30 degrees per minute), 150–300 °C (14 degrees per minute), 300 °C (2.95 min), 20 min total run time; 200 °C injector temperature. For the polar columns (SGE SOLGEL-WAX; 30 m × 0.25 mm × 25 μm): 50 °C (4 min), 50–200 °C (10 degrees per minute), 200 °C (1 min). Helium was used as the carrier gas with a constant 1 mL per minute flow. All EI-MS spectra were recorded with 70 eV energy. The identification of peaks at chromatograms was made by comparison of respective EI mass-spectra with those from the NIST v.2.0f database (PerkinElmer TurboMass v.5.4.2.1617 software). The mass-spectra patterns of tertiary dimethylcyclohexanols were not found in the NIST database, and identification of these products was made by comparing with the reported previously mass-spectra [19,27]. 2.3 Experiments with H2 18O The 18O-labeled water (97% of 18O, Sigma-Aldrich) was added prior the addition of m-CPBA. The 16O/18O compositions of oxygenated product (tertiary trans-alcohol formed from the trans-decaline substrate) were determined by the relative abundances of mass peaks at m/z = 154/156. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic system The general screening of the catalytic activities of the various phthalocyanines was performed using cis-1,2-dimehtylcyclohexane (cis-1,2-DMCH) as a simple model substrate. Hydroxylation of a tertiary bond of cis-1,2-DMCH typically proceeds either with retention of stereoconfiguration of the hydrocarbon motif or with its epimerization (Scheme 1 ), while the effect of inversion of stereoconfiguration is rather rare [28]. The stereoretention usually accounts for the absence of long-lived alkyl radicals and, therefore, this type of study allows to distinguish between different types of reaction mechanisms [6,29]. Oxidations with m-CPBA (as well as related aromatic peracids, such as peroxyphenylacetic acid) may proceed via a number of pathways, involving homolytic and heterolytic splittings of the OO bond (Scheme 2 ) [18]. Formation of aroyloxyl radical in the course of the homolytic splitting affords, after decarboxylation, chlorobenzene as a by-product. Thus, the chlorobenzene formation allows to make tentative conclusions about the homolytic process contribution. The use of an acidic promoter is known to be very useful in the peroxidative oxidation of alkanes, where acid plays multiple roles, e.g., promoting the formation of unsaturated metal coordination and the splitting of the peroxide OO bond. In the present investigation we employed nitric acid as a promoter. Detailed experiment data with the respective discussion is provided below. 3.2 Effect of the [M(Pc)] nature The catalytic screening of the phthalocyanine complexes [M(Pc)] and of Pc was performed and the results are summarized at Table 1 and Fig. 1 . Most of the studied complexes (Entries 1–4 and 6–8), as well as Pc (Entry 9), perform modestly towards the formation of oxygenated products, disclosing also a low selectivity together with low yields of chlorobenzene (Table 1). The catalyst-free reaction was also investigated (Entry 10), as m-CPBA oxidizes weak CH bonds, revealing only 3.2% yield based on the oxidant (corresponds to 0.8% of yield based on substrate). The maximum reached values of TON (turnover number, mols of products per mol of catalyst) in these tests did not exceed 26, but they are meaningless since the yields are of the same order of magnitude as that obtained with a metal-free system. Phthalocyanines of manganese and iron (Entries 3 and 4) were expected to show significant activities, since both complexes, as well as their porphyrin analogues, are known to form HVMO species, particularly upon reaction with m-CPBA [30,31]. However, the obtained experimental data show no prevalence of the [Fe(Pc)] and [Mn(Pc)] containing catalytic systems over most of the others (Fig. 1). In contrast, the [Co(Pc)] catalyst exhibits a prominent activity with very high retention of stereoconfiguration (RC > 98%) and yields of products up to 63% based on the oxidant (Table 1, Entry 5; Fig. 1). It was found that cobalt nitrate shows a comparable level of catalytic activity (Entry 11). The TON values, calculated for all products, were 194 and 158 for Co(NO3)2 and [Co(Pc)] catalysts, respectively. However, a lower 3° : 2° selectivity was observed for the Co(NO3)2 catalyst, what results in a higher sum yield of products. Also, the Co(NO3)2 catalyst resulted in an acetamide by-product (Fig. S2) which was not observed in the case of [Co(Pc)] (Entry 5). In the absence of nitric acid promoter both Co(NO3)2 and [Co(Pc)] catalysts show lower catalytic activity (Table 1, Entries 12 and 13). The yields of chlorobenzene based on the oxidant reached 5.9 and 13.8%, respectively, suggesting a significant contribution of the OO bond homolysis into the overall reaction mechanism (Scheme 2). We considered phthalocyanine complexes as more convenient objects for the catalytic study due to similarity of the structures and oxidation states of various [M(Pc)] compounds (except of [VO(Pc)] and pronounced colour changes, allowing monitoring the changes of electronic spectra of the catalytically active species. For [Co(Pc)], accumulation of the tertiary cis-alcohol is linear at the initial period 0–20 min, then reaches a plateau. For the same period of time, the initial reaction rate W 0 is 1.2 × 10–5 M s–1 (Fig. 2 , top), while the concentration of trans-alcohol exhibits a linear decay with W linear = 4.9 × 10–7 M s–1. Since the substrate, cis-1,2-DMCH, does not contain tertiary alcohols, one may conclude that a small amount of trans-alcohol is formed at the first seconds of the reaction. Accumulations of the reaction products for the [Fe(Pc)] catalyst, which shows a lower stereoselectivity with RC index of 72% (Table 1, Entry 4), are depicted in Fig. 2, bottom. In contrast to [Co(Pc)], the concentration of the tertiary trans-alcohol can be considered as constant at 2.2 × 10–4 M. The accumulation curve for the cis-alcohol shows a more complex behaviour (Fig. 2, bottom). The initial period of 0–10 min concerns the acute growth of the product concentration with W 0 of 2.1 × 10–5 M s–1. After that, a quasi-linear dependence in the 10–90 min region can be observed with W linear = 1.1 × 10–7 M s–1. Finally, the curve approaches a plateau. In an attempt to detect a possible synergic effect, we also studied the catalytic system comprising equimolar amounts of [Co(Pc)] and [Fe(Pc)]; their final concentrations were as those in Entries 5 and 4 (Table 1), respectively. The choice of iron phthalocyanine was governed by its good stereoselectivity parameters (Table 1) as well as the ability to form catalytically active dimeric phthalocyanine species [5,16,32–34]. With the studied Co(Pc)-Fe(Pc) combination, the yield of 29.3% was achieved, along with the RC index of 95.7% and normalized 3° : 2° bond selectivity of 28 : 1. The accumulation curve of the tertiary cis-alcohol is of linear type in the 0–20 min range with W 0 = 5.8 × 10–6 M (Fig. S1). Moreover, the initial reaction rate is ca. twice lower than that for [Co(Pc)] (1.2 × 10–5 M s–1). Hence, it appears that the catalytic activity of [Co(Pc)] was hampered by [Fe(Pc)] and no synergic effect is detected under the studied conditions. 3.3 Effect of the nature of oxidant The influence of the nature of oxidant was screened for the system cis-1,2-DMCH/[Co(Pc)]/HNO3, and the highest efficiency was observed for the m-CPBA oxidant (Table 2). Almost complete epimerization was detected for H2O2, as evidenced by the cis/trans ratio of 1.1 and RC of 5.8% (Table 2, Entry 15). Such observation suggests the participation of long-lived alkyl radicals as reaction intermediates (Scheme 1), typical for oxidations with H2O2 and hydroxyl radicals as attacking species [6]. Excluding m-CPBA, the best stereoselectivity among the other studied oxidants was achieved by using the peracetic acid (Table 2, Entry 17), while the best yield of products was provided by the 2,4-pentanedione peroxide (Entry 21). From Tables 1 and 2 it is clear that the combination of the Co(Pc) catalyst and m-CPBA is crucial for achieving the best parameters for the given catalytic oxidation. 3.4 Effect of additives Cyclohexane is a common substrate used to compare the CH activation ability of various catalysts [6]. Oxidation of cyclohexane with the [Co(Pc)]/HNO3/m-CPBA system afforded cyclohexanone as the main product (Table 3 , Entry 22). The maximum achieved yield of oxygenates was 32% based on the oxidant (Table 3, Entry 22). In this case, a twice higher yield of chlorobenzene (3.5%) was observed in comparison to the cis-1,2-DMCH substrate (1.6%, Entry 5, Table 1), suggesting a larger contribution of the m-CPBA homolysis to the overall mechanism (Scheme 2). As the next step, we attempted to functionalize cyclohexane with various groups by introducing the respective agents into the [Co(Pc)]/HNO3/m-CPBA catalytic system. Since halogenation of alkanes still remains a challenge [35–39], we started with HCl as an additive. It is known that m-CPBA in combination with HCl, at large concentrations, may halogenate phenols and alkynes [17], but not at the concentrations of the present study. A blank test employing HCl in a concentration equal to that of m-CPBA (0.025 M) revealed only a negligible halogenation. The presence of the catalyst, [Co(Pc)], accelerated the reaction towards chlorocyclohexane as the main C–H functionalization product with ca. 5% yield (Table 3, Fig. S3). At the same time, the formation of oxygenated products was suppressed and a higher alcohol/ketone (A/K) ratio was observed (Table 3, Entry 23). Isomers of dichlorocyclohexanes were detected as overhalogenation by-products. The detection of 1,3-dichlorobenzene (Fig. S3) is in accord with the presence of chlorobenzene radicals. Moreover, large amounts of acetamide were detected, presumably formed upon hydrolysis of the acetonitrile solvent. With N-bromosuccinimide (NBS) as the additive, the main products were cyclohexanone (with admixture of cyclohexanol, 32% of sum yield) and bromocyclohexane (24% yield) (Table 3, Entry 24; yields based on m-CPBA). Only small quantities of acetamide were detected, in contrast to the above experiment with HCl. As the 3-bromochlorobenzene by-product was detected (Fig. S4), one can suggest the prevalent homolysis of the OO bond of m-CPBA in a free radical process. The oxygenated products are formed in an identical amount to that for the additive-free reaction (Entry 22). Iodobenzene, particularly in combination with m-CPBA, is known as an intermediate in some oxidative processes [17]. However, in the present case the iodobenzene additive caused almost complete suppression of the catalytic activity (Entry 25, Table 3), with no iodocyclohexane detected. It was also demonstrated that azides can promote oxidation processes via formation of azide radical [40,41]. In spite of that, when the oxidation of cyclohexane with the catalytic system [Co(Pc)]/HNO3/m-CPBA was performed in the presence of NaN3, the formation of oxygenates was suppressed down to 4% yield (Table 3, Entry 26), with rather high A/K ratio of 2.2. No cyclohexyl azide was detected, while the amounts of chlorobenzene reached 8% yield, the highest detected value for all the tests (Entry 26). Recently it was shown that benzamide can amidate alkanes, including cyclohexane, via a free radical mechanism using peroxides as terminal oxidants [42]. However, no N-cyclohexyl benzamide was obtained in the case of the [Co(Pc)]/HNO3/m-CPBA catalytic system (Table 3, Entry 27), while the presence of benzamide caused twice lower yields of oxygenates compared to the additive-free system. The observation of the halogenation products for cyclohexane substrate (Table 3, Entries 23 and 24) suggested to check if stereoconfiguration is retained during the halogenation of cis-1,2-dimethylcyclohexane. The respective tests revealed that both HCl/m-CPBA and NBS/m-CPBA systems do not afford stereoselective halogenation (Figs. S5–S8). 3.5 Effect of the substrate nature The results of oxidation of the substrates related to cis-1,2-DMCH are summarized in Table 4 . For these studies we selected [Co(Pc)] and [Fe(Pc)] as the catalysts showing the highest RC index (Table 1). For the cobalt catalyst, all the substrates retain well their stereoconfiguration with yields of products up to 75%. The respective parameters for the iron phthalocyanine are much lower, especially normalized bond selectivity, which drops to 2 for trans-decaline (Table 4, Entry 30). Oxidation of R-(–)-menthyl acetate (RMA) was performed to check the regiospecific features of the [Co(Pc)] and [Fe(Pc)] catalytic systems. This substrate contains three tertiary CH bonds of different sterical accessibilities (Scheme 3 ). The chromatograms of the reaction products (Fig. S9) revealed the presence of tertiary alcohols as the main reaction products, with the ratios depicted in Scheme 3. The ratios of the products show no significant preference between all the three tertiary positions (Scheme 3). The stereoconfiguration of the RMA substrate seems to be retained, as each peak at the chromatograms is assigned to a single product (Fig.S9). For comparison, the oxidation of RMA with hydroxyl radicals formed by the FeCl3/HNO3/H2O2 system [43,44] led to epimerization of the stereoconfiguration of the tertiary carbon with the hydroxyl group of the alcohol (1) (Figs. S12–S15). 3.6 Reactions in the presence of H2 18O Incorporation of 18O from H2 18O is an important indicator of the presence of HVMO species, which are known to exchange oxygen with water via oxo-hydroxo tautomerism [15,45]. We performed oxidations of trans-decaline using [Co(Pc)], [Fe(Pc)] and [Ni(Pc)] catalysts in the presence of H2 18O (1.4 M). The nickel phthalocyanine was added to the study due to its unusually high 3°: 2° bond selectivity (Table 1, Entry 6). The choice of the substrate was governed by the observation of strong molecular ion peaks in its mass-spectrum and relatively high yields of the respective tertiary alcohol. The results are summarized in Scheme 4 . The incorporation of 18O into the alcohol is at a low level, not exceeding 4%. Such amounts are close to that (3.5%) observed for the promoter-free oxidation of cis-1,2-DMCH with m-CPBA, catalysed by the cobalt isoindole and Schiff base complexes [19,46]. These observations point out to the non-involvement of HVMO species as relevant intermediates in the oxidation process. It should be also noted that there is no evidence for the direct oxygen exchange between decaline tertiary alcohol and water, as the amounts of 18O in the alcohol do not increase with the time. For all three studied catalysts, the 18O level remained the same after 24 h. 3.7 UV/Vis spectroscopy The UV/Vis spectrum of the acetonitrile solution of [Co(Pc)] (4 × 10–7 M) shows numerous absorption bands in the visible and near-ultraviolet region (Fig. 3 ), while the Q-band (π→π* transition) [25] is located at 660 nm. The addition of nitric acid promoter causes rapid changes in the spectrum (Figs. 3 and S16): a band at 660 nm shifts to 663 nm and quickly grows, reaching a maximum at 2 min (Fig. S18), then a gradual decay is observed, while new strong absorptions at 526 and 704 nm appear (Fig. 3, top). These bands suggest that protonation of the cobalt phthalocyanine occurs at the beginning, then [Co(Pc)] reacts with atmospheric dioxygen to form π-cation radical species [CoIII(Pc(1–))]•2+, as evidenced by characteristic absorption band at 526 nm [47,48]. Addition of m-CPBA to the solution of [Co(Pc)] with HNO3 causes gradual decline of the overall absorption, while a new band appears at 392 nm (Fig. 3, bottom; Fig. S17). These results confirm that the phthalocyanine catalyst does not degrade immediately even in the presence of > 6 × 104 excess of the oxidant. Such data are in accord with earlier observations that phthalocyanine and porphyrin complexes are stable and catalytically active in the presence of similar amounts of m-CPBA [33]. 3.8 Discussion The accumulated experimental evidences demonstrate a pronounced activity of cobalt phthalocyanine in the oxidation of sp3 CH bonds with m-CPBA. The presence of cobalt is essential, as all the other studied metals are much less effective (Fig. 1). The initial formation of the tertiary trans-alcohol in the course of cis-1,2-DMCH oxidation (Fig. 2, top) accounts for the presence of a short initial period when the tertiary trans-alcohol forms. During the next period (until 20 min) this trans-alcohol gradually undergoes overoxidation. The initial “intermediate” period could be assigned to a fast free-radical mechanism, which is then suppressed by the main process. Careful inspection of the chromatograms revealed the presence of alkene by-products, which are better seen if larger amounts of the catalyst are taken (Fig. S19). Formation of alkenes from alkanes is expected for metal-catalysed radical processes [49]. In the present case, however, this should be a short-lived alkyl radical; otherwise, epimerization of stereoconfiguration would occur. It is often proposed for highly selective metal-catalysed oxidative reactions that Con O HVMO (n = IV or V) species are responsible for the stereospecific oxidation. The presence of short-lived alkyl radicals is in agreement with the presence of HVMO species, as the latter may be oxidized via a fast radical rebound mechanism. However, in the present case there are the following contradictions to such an assumption: (a) The dependences of the bond selectivity parameters on the substrate are similar for both [Fe(Pc)] and [Co(Pc)] (Tables 1 and 4). For example, for both complexes the selectivities are higher for the cis-substrates. Thus, cis-decaline (Entry 29, Table 4) gives the best yields and RC indexes for both catalysts. Moreover, the respective selectivity parameters follow those studied previously for the alkane oxidation with m-CPBA and cobalt isoindole and Schiff base complexes [19,46]. (b) The stereoconfiguration of R-(–)-menthyl acetate is retained during the oxidation, but the selectivity between the three tertiary sites of different accessibility is surprisingly low and do not depend on the nature of the catalyst, [Co(Pc)] or [Fe(Pc)] (Scheme 3). For comparison, the complexes of iron, known to oxidize CH bonds with FeIV O or FeV O HMVO species, show (3) : (2) selectivities (Scheme 3) from 5 : 1 to 17 : 1, while the position (1) is not oxidized at all due to sterical hindrance [50–53]. The low positional selectivity of the [M(Pc)]/HNO3/m-CPBA system in the oxidation of R-(–)-menthyl acetate suggests that the attacking species is relatively small and flexible. Phthalocyanine, being a bulky ligand, should reveal greater degree of discrimination between (1) : (2) : (3) sites of R-(–)-menthyl acetate. (c) Incorporation of H2 18O into the alcohols does not depend much on the nature of catalyst (Scheme 4). Moreover, incorporations of the same magnitude were reported earlier for the reactions performed using the m-CPBA oxidant, although without the acidic promoter. The presence of small amounts of 18O in the alcohol product do not support the involvement of HVMO species (although does not contradict them). Hence, a possible mechanism may involve catalytic formation of metal-free active species generated from m-CPBA and possessing high selectivity properties. This could be, for instance, the aroylperoxyl radical ArC(O)OO [18,54,55], formed through the reaction of aroyloxyl radical ArC(O)O with the [M(Pc)–(m-CPBA)] intermediate. The type of mechanism could resemble that for the recently discovered metal-fee oxidation of aromatic CH bonds with phthaloyl peroxide, where a reverse-rebound mechanism is proposed [56]. In this way, although we cannot exclude participation of HVMO species, the role of the metal catalyst in the [Co(Pc)]/HNO3/m-CPBA system is most likely to generate active species towards an alkane CH bond and suppress possible side reactions. 4 Conclusions In this work, we studied the catalytic activity of a series of phthalocyanine complexes in the mild homogeneous hydroxylation of sp3 CH bonds with m-CPBA oxidant in the presence of nitric acid promoter. The influence of the nature of the [M(Pc)] catalyst on the selectivity parameters was studied, disclosing an exclusively high stereoselectivity and activity of cobalt phthalocyanine. Accordingly, the catalytic system [Co(Pc)]/HNO3/m-CPBA reveals a very high level of stereoretention of >98% together with a high yield of oxygenates of 63% (based on the oxidant) and a high preference towards oxidation of tertiary CH bonds. The influence of the nature of the oxidant was also studied, showing much lower efficiency for oxidants other than m-CPBA. The stereoselective properties were studied for a range of model substrates, always showing high stereoretention of no less than 95%. The catalytic system [Co(Pc)]/HNO3/m-CPBA represents a rare case of an oxidation system able to provide notable yields of products together with high stereoselectivity. It was also checked if the catalytic system can perform oxidative functionalization of CH bonds to give amide, azide or halogen derivatives, and it was found that cyclohexane can be transformed to chloro- or bromocyclohexane in the presence of HCl or N-bromosuccinimide additive, respectively. The mechanism of the performed catalytic hydroxylation is complex and proceeds at least in two stages. The analysis of selectivity, as well as the by-products, allowed to consider short-lived alkyl radicals as intermediates. However, no evidence for the presence of high-valent metal-oxo attacking species was obtained. The detailed study of the reaction mechanism and identification of active intermediates is underway. As a final remark, this work points out that the catalytic activity of phthalocyanine complexes towards mild functionalization of alkane CH bonds deserves to be further explored. coredata.dc:description: A series of phthalocyanine (Pc) complexes of general formula [M(Pc)] (M = Mg, V, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) was tested as catalysts for functionalization of sp3 CH bonds, namely in the mild stereoselective oxidation of cyclic alkanes (isomers of dimethylcyclohexane and decahydronaphthalene) using peroxides as oxidants. A high catalytic activity (yield of products up to 75% based on the oxidant) and outstanding retention of stereoconfiguration of substrates (>95% for isomers of dimethylcyclohexane) was disclosed for the cobalt phthalocyanine catalyst [Co(Pc)] using m-chloroperbenzoic acid (m-CPBA) as oxidant and nitric acid as promoter. The phthalocyanine complexes other than Co are much less active with yields of products <10% and low stereo- and bond selectivities. The main reaction mechanism is proposed not to involve high-valent metal species, as evidenced by 18O-labeling and selectivity studies. The [Co(Pc)]/HNO3/m-CPBA system also catalyses chlorination and bromination of cyclohexane with HCl and N-bromosuccinimide as halogen sources.
coredata.dc:title: Pronounced retention of stereoconfiguration upon sp3 CH bonds hydroxylation of dimethylcyclohexanes and decahydronaphthalenes with m-CPBA oxidant and a Co-phthalocyanine catalyst
